>>53183616
>misty has never had a "real" goal other than be a good gym leader
People often wave Misty off saying she just wants to be a gym leader (so she should just go home right now lolol), BUT that is not entirely true. Misty's stated goal in the series was to be the greatest master of water pokemon. It's vague, just like Ash's goal to become a pokemon master in the broader sense.

So that means she and Ash share virtually the same "real" goal. That lends credibility to the idea of her just fucking off with Ash because they both chase the same ideal of being a master, the difference being Misty wants to be a specialist and Ash wants to be a general practitioner.

And like anon said, her dream is to be like Lorelei of the Elite Four. This is actually lifted straight from the games. Coincidentally, she also has dialog in the games stating she wants to go on a journey to get stronger after training at her gym.

That, and the lore from Sun/Moon dex entries stating that some Primeape become so angry that they die always kind of implied going into cardiac arrest, either through blood pressure being far to high for too long and causing arterial disease, or takotsubo syndrome (look it up), or both—then when they designed Annihilape they gave it marks on the wrists where one cuff used to be and where the crack on the other is now which /could/ be muscles but look much more like veins.
So yeah, the broken cuff metaphorically does a great job of representing it being untethered from its mortal coil, but it also visually implies that when the Primeape evolved, it did so by elevating its blood pressure so impossibly, cartoonishly high that it shattered the metal bands it was wearing /and/ killed it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53180869
Evasion and accuracy chicanery ends up just being bad manners. Thats its problem. One double team could theoretically win you an entire game just based on dice rolls.
Its simply uninteresting and doesn't require any planning to pull off. To be countered it just requires using the many ---% accuracy attacks that are all generally low power. Turning beating the strategy into a slog and not a challenging one.
ParaFlinch is different from say, putting Bright Powder and Double Team on a monster, because it requires set up. You have to get that Thunder Wave, and you have to use a monster with Serene Grace and then rely on less than 100% accuracy moves like Air Slash. It can easily backfire on you and can be played around skillfully without making everything a drag.

What is so hard about accepting that GameFreak clearly wants the game to be played in a quick and offensive manner, rather than anything like 'balance' or 'stall'?
Was them gutting Stall strats widely not proof of that? Just play the game they want you to. Stop banning everything so your fanfiction is allowed to work as you wish it did, instead of how it actually does.

>>53185105
Because Marill is more of a Pika-homage than a Pikaclone. Gen II was made at a time when the line between generations was nebulous. The Gen 2 dex was effectively just "all Pokemon that existed" so making a Pikachu replaement wouldn't really make sense. This means that despite all the guff that Gen II gets for "not having an identity" and "leaning on Kanto" Gen II's "Pikaclone" ended up as the least derivative. In another twist of Irony, Despite Gen II Pokemon being looked down on as "Shitmons" due to unfortunatelybearing the brunt of powercreep, since Johto get net to no shilling from Game FReak or TPC, the Marill line is only gotten better over time and even in the most powercrept generation ever its still a solid pokemon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53186200
>Typhlosion
Flamethrower (STAB fire attack, good damage)
Drain Punch (helps against rocks, gives Typhlosion a recovery option)
Infernal Parade (STAB ghost move, more PP than shadow ball and extra damage if they're burned)
Thunderpunch (water weakness coverage, good for weakneing certain pokemon to catch, didn't use wild charge because the recoil damage seemed like an issue)
>Staraptor
Close Combat (covers rock weakness, big damage, every Staraptor has this move)
Brave Bird (big damage flying type move)
Aerial Ace (for when I need less power and more accuarcy)
Roost (healing move, helps deal with Brave Bird's downside)
>Ursaluna
Thunderpunch (hits water and flying types well and covers the former's weakness)
High Horsepower (big damage ground move in a game with no earthquake)
Ice Punch (hits grass types and flying 'mons that resist electric, and a physical option against dragons)
Headlong Rush (Ground Type Close Combat, for when you really need something gone)
>Gardevoir
Energy Ball (nothing on this team had a grass type move already and energy ball still hits water/ground/rock types good)
Moonblast (STAB fairy move)
Psychic (STAB psychic move, beats Poison types which could kill Gardevoir)
Aura Sphere (hits steel types, one of Gardevoir's weaknesses)
>Goodra
Sludge Bomb (anti-fairy move)
Dragon Pulse (STAB dragon move)
Shellter (good for defense/evasion boosting, probably could've replaced it with iron head or steel beam desu)
Hydro Pump (fuck them ground types)
>Samurott
Night Slash (STAB dark move, although I ran Ceaseless Edge for most of the playthrough)
Megahorn (anti-grass type move)
Aqua Tail (big damage physical water move)
Psycho Cut (anti-fighting type move)

Most of their moves were meant to cover their weaknesses, since it seemed like a lot of pokemon in PLA had or knew moves that not only covered their weaknesses, but also were moves that could beat my pokemon as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Polished, because it's just cool. I played Crystal Clear and the typical /vp/ grievances didn't bother me. What bothered me was how aimless the game feels. It's a novel idea, but it's clearly just an experiment. It accomplishes what it set out to do, but that's all. Polished aggravates me because it uses that buzzword (more polish!!!) in its title, and even though it forms a nice pun, it's still irritating to think someone somewhere thought Crystal needed these additions to be "improved". With that being said, I appreciate every addition to Polished I can recall. I enjoy the new area in Ecruteak City, adding in Lyra (I think she takes the last starter too) and the way trade evolutions are now stat based. It's all pretty fucking cool, and because these are just additions to a pre-existing game that doesn't just set you down and tell you to do whatever, it feels way more immersive than Crystal Clear, which ironically is supposed to be your self-insert simulator. There's just nothing going ON in Crystal Clear, so the Open World shit means nothing.

If the CC dev actually had a story that changed based on where you began, now that would be ridiculously impressive, but that sounds hard as balls and very time-consuming, so I don't blame him for not doing it.

posts.com:
>>53181844
Funny this thread showed up, I just finished back-to-back playthroughs of both last weekend. CC isn't bad but it's main draw is the "starting from almost anywhere" and no borders between Gyms, so you can fight them in any order and that's about it. The Pokédex interface is leagues better and genuinely useful when needing to quickly check something (eg. egg groups). It's great if you want to do a mono-type run or something as you can easily get anywhere to build a team.

Polished Crystal though is just a modernized version of Crystal. But the changes the creator did make are nice and don't feel out of places. My main complaints are shit like the "Hidden Grottos" - features that are only really half-introduced. I believe there's only four in the game, and they're all in Johto, so it very much feels like something the creator was like "hey this will be cool" then forgot about after adding some. Box management though is a lot better in Polished Crystal, and I don't mind the Pokémon distribution much, though it's a shame some had to be removed due to space.

It's tough to compare them as a whole though because they're both aiming for something very different. CC is just aiming to be an open world version of Crystal, but Polished Crystal is aiming to be more in-line with modern Pokémon games (battle mechanics, physical/special split, natures, etc)

I think if someone was a big fan of vanilla gen2 I'd recommend Polished Crystal, but if they were a fan of older JRPGs I'd recommend CC.

I wonder if either of them is ever going to receive a future update

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53161862
>Give it +10pts in SpAtt, bringing BST to 530 and SpAtt to 110
>Buff Illuminate so that it increases your Accuracy +2 each time you use a "light" move (happens before the attack goes off) and each time you are hit with a Dark move (happens after damage). This way there's a specific set up condition that isn't as simple as switching in. You reap the benefit for setting it up but it also means that people just can't send in this Pokémon and start spammimg Blizzard. Light moves would be moves like Dazzling Gleam, a lot of the Beam moves, etc.
>Replace Analytic with Hydration or Regenerator. Either makes way more sense and neither takes away from it also having Natural Cure as well
>Keep Meteor Beam and Flip Turn in its base moveset (they were cut from BDSP). It already learns a lot of really good offensive moves, but I would also give it access to Energy Ball, Whirlpool, Chilling Water, Acid Spray and Stored Power. I'm going to assume it would also get Tera Blast and Ice Spinner, even if the second is kinda pointless.
>Give it back a lot of the status moves it lost in Gen 8: Swagger, Psych Up, Confide, Reflect Type, Camouflage, Toxic and Spotlight. It already has Cosmic Power, but let's give it Acupressure and Growth too. It has such a wide move pool that I don't want it to feel overpowered if it's going to get Accuracy boosts on top of access to Nasty Plot or CM. Acupressure makes sense because it's a sea star, and I feel like Growth would be an interesting gimmicky setup move that does make sense on it. I also really want it to have Autotomize and Coil, because it's a goddamn sea star. Why wouldn't it be able to cut off a limb or curl up its body? Both would be super gimmicky as well but fun set up moves nonetheless

All right, how did I do? I'm already picturing a Doubles set that uses something like Dazzling Gleam, Hydro Pump, Thunder and Blizzard with Illuminate and holding a Weakness Policy w an ally using Brutal Swing

Hoeen most likely has more shitmons by both volume and percentage but there are other factors
>Hoenn was allowed to have more pokemon overall so its easier to ignore the embarrassing shitmons, while Johto was stuck with only 100 due to technological limitations
>Johto's weakest pokemon are worse than Hoeen's weakest pokemon, Luvdisc is an embarrassment but it actually has moves unlike Unown, and the Hoenn bugs are shit and would be the weakest if not for Ledian existing, Also, they got ever so slightly better due to Quiver Dance, unlike Ledian which has only ever gotten worse and worse, being actively mocked with Iron Fist, replaced by Orbeetle, and erased from the franchise
>Hoeen only has two baby pokemon compared to Johto's 8
>TPC did a far better job at marketing the cooler stronger Pokemon during Gen 3, meanwhile during Gen 2 way too much attention to the baby pokemon that no one liked; this is partly why GEen2 is seen as "babyish" and why some people think Skarmory is a Gen 3 pokemon
>Hoenn starters are probably the second most pandered to outside of Kanto's, being given great stats and typing's on release and constantly getting new moves, great abilities and even getting the honor of megas. Meanwhile Johto's starters are infamously weak due to being neglected and hated by someone at Game Freak, with the biggest slap in the face being skipped over for megas despite needing them more than any other set of starters
>Similar story with the Box legends, Kanto's Mewtwo, and Hoenns weather trio got broken special snowflake forms while the the Johto box Legends got..nothing. Though Ho-oh seems to at least still be usable as an Uber unlike Lugia.

tdlr: Hoeen may technically be weaker on average, but it got saved by shilling, Johto wasn't allowed to have that privilege for some reason, so Johto's stuck being the "shitmon region".

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53154813
>What are you reading currently?
Just proofin' something non-fandom.

>What are you writing currently?
I got half of a chapter on my current WIP, which having been writer's blocked for a few years now will hopefully get over that hump.

>What’s your favorite kind of fic? (Recommendations?)
The kind that challenges its characters to deal with problems, not merely act out "being in the world of the IP" or "let's save the day" kinds of tropes.

>>Which Pokemon do you wish got featured more in stories?
I think that it's good that many species don't get featured much. There are so many kinds of pokemon that it makes sense that some simply don't inhabit places or exhibit behaviors that put it in the kinds of places where interesting fiction happens. The other side of this is that when a rarely featured pokemon appears, it needs to hit a home run and demonstrate what it uniquely has to offer a narrative while also showing that we should be happy not to see it too often. That preserves the mystique and gets the most mileage out of relatively untrodden paths.

>>Author QOTT: What’s one thing about creating a story you wish readers understood better?
That the author has no idea how what's written will be received. Scenes I felt were kinda dull connectors have stolen spotlights and bits I thought were profound have fallen flat. So while compliments on a work as a whole are well appreciated, it's comments on the individual bits that hit or missed that can provide actionable feedback letting the author develop a second-person perspective on how the piece looks to a reader on the other side of the screen.

posts.name: Purple Blaziken
posts.com:
>>53155025
Exactly what you describe in terms of needing to justify the usage of niche species in order to fairly give them a spotlight is what I’m going for in my Mystery Dungeon story. It’s a long story with a big world, so I have a lot in mind to showcase some underloved Pokemon without feeling like they’re being forced into relevance. That’s what I always loved about playing the Mystery Dungeon series and it’s something I’m strongly trying to carry over into my own take on the concept. For example, Diglett or Bidoof or Loudred are not Pokemon I ever would’ve thought could make for entertaining/interesting characters until I saw them in action in Mystery Dungeon. I’d love readers to have that same feeling, that “Aha!” moment that allows them to see a shitmon/obscure pick in a new light.

I also totally love your answer for the QOTT, I feel like that’s something that goes across all entertainment media: painters, musicians, actors, writers; often times it’s the work we expect to hit hard that gets glanced over and the work that we second guess that lands a home run with the audiences. I agree with your note on specific feedback, but think an equally valid way forward (that you could totally do in conjunction) would be to always keep your stories fresh and diverse in terms of emotion, word choice, structure, plot, character, etc; feeling like I’m reading the same chapter twice in a row is my worst feeling as a reader, so it’s my worst fear as an author, I don’t think you should ever let a story stagnate. You can still adjust to your successes and losses and tell a perfectly fluid story without allowing style or standards to stagnate.

Best of luck on clearing your block, you got it!

>>53166431
I've dabbled with something like that, though not for pokemon in particular. As far as I discovered in my brief stint into that sort of thing, it's rather important that you don't think of the story as just a one-to-one extension of exactly what happened in the game. It's difficult to steer away from an outright novelization, but altering in-game and mechanical events to spin your own story/character seems to work out the best. Just off the top of my head, you could write a struggling party member with shit stats or nature as having a completely different made-up problem which then creates a conflict in the story. You'd also probably play the game incrementally with progressing your writing.

>I've got to ask, why did you choose to make a specific site and AI-gen map for a fic that has sub 10k words at the moment?
Why: If one feels more comfortable, and more likely to succeed, at ancillary works, they will be more attractive than doing the hard and uncertain writing part.
To what end: Sunk cost. With a site done, that becomes encouragement not to let the site languish. With a map done, that's something can be looked at for inspiration or guidance of "where to go next," just like an outline serves as a map for a plot when one is writing for a predetermined arc.

>I can't imagine going through all that effort
It may be less effort. If one is familiar with making sites or telling an AI to roll a seed and spit out a map, then "all that effort" is really not effort, it's play.


As for me, no sites, my map is a scrap of paper I penciled some notes on. But I'd sure let computer tools do the heavy lifting for me if I needed to create a map that looked like something other than crap. Kudos.

And on top of that, flowery is just my style for this project, which I know not everyone loves, but I think it’s perfect for PMD. Those games have the perfect balance between immature spirit and soapy schmaltzy drama, a style that I think works perfectly and has given me so much inspiration over the years that I had to try my best to incorporate it into the written word.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53168964
I already did. I was the pmd thread critique. I think that your descriptions are weak because you rely too heavily on adverbs and by applying adjectives rather than exploring more interesting ways to convey imagery, as well as falling into telling behavior. But I'll elaborate on that if I must. Let's take something from the second chapter.

>“Buddy, you better watch your mouth,” Zangoose grows super serious, clearly offended and now speaking in a tone that’s making me feel increasingly unsafe.

"Grows super serious" is a telling statement, which is always a weaker alternative to applying context. As is the continuation stating that he's "clearly offended" and "making [Nathan] feel unsafe". This is simply a weak way to demonstrate something that was already given to the reader if only based on what Zangoose had already said. It's pretty clear that he's offended already, and that the Natu is in a precarious position to be pissing people off, but I understand that you wanted to express the change of tone and Nathan's fear. Were I to write out the same thing myself, it'd probably be a bit something like:

>"Buddy, you better watch your mouth," Zangoose snapped. I wince at the tone of his voice, trying to make myself small in my sling, but he continued to shout.

It's maybe not the best, or even what you wanted out of that sentence, but it's not mincing any words. It has a speech tag that assists the sudden shift in tone, a physical reaction from Nathan that denotes his mental state and provides physical imagery, and a way to denote that Zangoose is going to continue speaking.

It's things like that you can improve on with your prose. It should go without saying that having sentences like "Adjacent to this is a gently flowing river of crystal clear freshwater," can be a road bump in the reader's pacing and generally just rambles on implicit details to what you already describe as a vital, life-giving water source.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53169385
Agreed. In addition to the meme baggage of "super serious" (evoking memories of the South Park running gag with Al Gore saying "super cereal" instead as a malaprop) it's also evocative of childish and adolescent speech patterns that use adjectives for superlative emphasis.

The problem with the original line, and what can be improved in Anon's suggestion, is that there is an unexploited opportunity (as Anon mentions) to SHOW Zangoose's emotional transition rather than TELL it after the fact. This needs to be done first, because it colors the spoken part. As originally written—some sort of dialog tag with present tense narration that's jumping out of POV (I presume this is narrator-as-protagonist and doing kind of a stream of consciousness thing to justify present tense) awkwardly for the sake of presuming something—it's closer to a script, which isn't disallowed, but it's easy to get into a habit of just writing the spoken lines and tagging, forgetting that when we shift attention we must refresh the portrayal.

Ex.

(MC says something stupid.)

Zangoose's ears twitched and his eyes narrowed. He squared up his posture and sucked a sharp breath while the fur across his shoulders stood on end. "Buddy," he growled deeply, "you'd better watch your mouth." He leaned in, and I felt so threatened I couldn't help but to sink into my sling, feeling small and needy of protection.

>river thing
This is a fault of overloading one sentence. Long sentences can be cool, but they still need to be about one thing.

"Adjacent to this is a gently flowing river. Its waters are fresh, safe to drink, and crystal clear."

Two sentences cover two separate things—the river as a waterway and the water that flows in said waterway—and allows both to be better served without truly reducing the amount of described detail. Indeed, I've increased it, but it's easier to read because it's following an introduction/description pattern rather than wadding the whole thing up.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53155636
Sc 1 - I'm reminded of children's books I read long ago. I would not consider this a good thing.

Sc 2/3 - Were it not for my decision to give the entirety of the first chapter a read-through I would have stopped reading here. Cliche, rote, tired, - take your pick, whatever you like, they are all an accurate summary of these two scenes. Wholly unnecessary and baffling in their inclusion unless the aim is to heap still more young adult fiction onto the already burgeoning pile that exists with little regard for the appetite the audience has for higher lit. Aim for the smaller pile - everyone will be happier for it.

It is not lost on me this is fan fiction, but [good] fan fiction should make you forget that.

Sc 4 - See above.

Sc 5 - My attention unravels.

You show things that aren't necessary, and tell things that are. The overall construction of the work makes it abundantly clear that whoever is penning the prose knows how to write, but only in one specific way, and that way is long past its service-by date.

That's my best attempt at being succinct, because I don't want to spend an hour taking a fine-toothed comb to this. I will instead offer up a suggestion: Read Nisioisin. I feel the author will likely give you plenty of ideas and techniques to chew on that you could integrate into the parts of the work. He's character-focused and dialogue heavy, so he's not a good source for building up skills when it comes to exposition, but there are plenty of authors that do that as is.

Side note: Really, there's no need to run the PMD introduction gauntlet (sc. 2/3). It is exists for and in service of the gameplay, and it has no business being in a piece of prose when what it establishes could be better handled in scenes dedicated to showing what the questions try to illustrate. This is a common pitfall that dozens and dozens of PMD writers fall victim to and it is confusing to me every single time to find yet another body blinking up at me from the hole.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53179891
>I thought most AIs were programmed to explicitly avoid such things.
The general public services are strongly encouraged to censor prompts and output because they can get scapegoated for the prompts of people who might use the tool to break taboos. But it's trivial for someone with beefy GPU to go to a site with tagged art that is relevant to their interests and train on what they want. So, an e6-trained model's going to give e6 kinds of results. (e6 has an AI output counterpart now, btw, but it's very low traffic.)

Caveat emptor, what goes into a model is what comes out. It's like super lossy compression with super error correction on a portfolio to be used for photo collage. I would advise against downloading anything that isn't specifically trained within the art sites that you're comfortable browsing or that comes from dubious sources. I've been sticking to links to one of the least-seedy looking model sites (Civit AI). And once you have one good model, you can play with loras to get a lot of interesting results; they're like game mods and even if it's not for what you intend at low power it can make output a lot less generic.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53180169
There might be some room to play with the raised/trained by pokemon angle insofar as in canon we have people (e.g. psychics, black belts) who train with pokemon and seem to pick up a tiny fraction of the power. Having him raised by the correct species could allow for a human character with interesting poke-characteristics, but only if it's relevant to the core conflict.

Which is missing from this elevator pitch.

There's not much conflict in someone wondering what "kind of pokemon" he is when either he's been among very few kinds (and would know that he's significantly different and be ignorant of the thousand kinds of pokemon that could be alternatives for him to try to identify with) or many kinds (he would presume that he's just another kind that the other pokemon aren't familiar with) and resolving it wouldn't really change him or develop his character. And being not inculcated with complicated philosophical crap like "place in ecosystem/society/etc" to muddy his mind, he would probably figure his place to be wherever he's been, doing what he's been doing.

If the core conflict is wild-man versus society by having him be rediscovered, you've got a lot of fish-out-of-water tropes at hand, most of which having been worked to death already in mass media.

(cont)

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53181348
I think a more interesting angle would be to completely avoid humanity and to make this human the plot mechanic: Perhaps amid a desert is a natural spring that has created an oasis. Pokemon living there were divided into two groups that were each internally at peace and cooperative, but avoided each other due to type interactions meaning some of A could beat B but some of B could beat A so if they fought it'd be high casualties for both sides. But now the water is running out and the oasis is shrinking as the plant life withers. The circle is closing in and Battle Royale mode seems unavoidable, soon. The spoiler: B has been raising the lost child of human explorers who perished, and now it's the pokemon of A are the ones trying to figure out what a human is, why it has no familiar powers (or only very slightly picked up from the B pokemon as discussed above), but seems to have other abilities, including that the B pokemon seem to rally around it in ways that pokemon didn't normally behave.

Then the conflict becomes a battle for resources but with a development arc of whether or not Human will continue to function as a pokemon, or if the pressure of a fight for survival will push him into the role of a trainer and develop into a more human personality. That gives the story a question to discuss and answer, allows you to tackle the eternal unresolved nature-nurture topic, shoot your scenes from pokemon perspectives and have an interesting role reversal where the pokemon can talk but the human cannot communicate beyond gestures and familiar vocalizations, and you can avoid lots of the Tarzan Makes Contact tropes that would easily bog things down and make the story pick up some of the feel of a rehash.

I followed a guide that had me go through the challenges in proper level scaling, so for example, Katy > Rock Titan > Brassius > Flying Titan > Giancomo etc.
I allowed myself to only catch Pokemon, don't battle or do repeats unless for dex purposes, battling trainers as my main source of exp and only using New Pokemon, and cycling through them every 5 levels, so anytime a pokemon reached, for example, Level 25, I would swap it with another new Pokemon that was level 20 until they are all on equal levels.

>>53186172
>he is three years old and he loves Pokémon

Your post is good, but this stuck out to me. Make sure you're buying this for yourself and not for him or for some interest of yours that you're placing on him. He's three. He's going to love a lot of things in his young life and things will come in and out of favor wildly quickly.

Not saying he won't like pokemon tomorrow, but it wouldn't be unheard of among kids. Also, he's 3 and has little concept of these things.

Ultimately, buy it for yourself and because it reminds you of yourself in your youth, and because it also reminds you of your son (along with the rarity of it). But get it for you, not for him. You can give it to him down the line, of course, but you get the gist of what I'm saying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53179987
>Cubone at least has multihits, and a 2 hit ranged attack
In theory, you are correct.
In practice, there are some problems with that:
Cubone learns Bone Rush at Level 41. That's well into the postgame, so that doesn't help you with the parts of them game that both Cubone and Machop struggle the most with.
Bonemerang is learn upon Level 25. If you play through the game without grinding, you typically reach that around Magma Cavern/Sky Tower.
Sky Tower is particular is filled with Flying Types and Pokemon that have levitate, so it isn't nearly as useful as you might think. Also, the accuracy is terrible.

After Rayquaza, you can reliably farm gummies and TMs so the difference between the two becomes rather insignificant, at least in my experience.

The only starter to have that is Charmander, since Charizard can learn Heatwave immediately (Problem being of course that you have to grind another 10 leveln on average, but basically every starter needs to grind lul).
I used to just go recruit Arcticuno immideately for that reason, since it come high level and with an excellent movepool that includes Powder Snow. Problem with that is or course its size. Your teams combined Size cannot exceed 6, and Articuno already has a size of 4, so you cannot use it to recruit most of the other big legendaries.
honestly, the best way to play the original rescue team ist probably to pick Charmandar as a starter along with something busted to carry you until postgame, then dump all your gummies into Charmandar all at once and solo the rest of the game with Charizard.

posts.sub: 1 of every pokemon vs 1 billion lions
posts.com:
alrighty /vp/ lets settle this

the rules for the fight are as follows
the fight will be conducted in an in-game environment, since transposing pokemon into the real world is messy as the lore is unclear
for the purposes of the fight, real-world lions will be transposed into pokemon, using pyroar as a base. they have mostly the same stat spread (BST 507) but with atk and spatk swapped, so they have 109 atk and 106 speed. their moves are
- crunch
- noble roar
- work up
- rest
they are mono-normal and get either intimidate, moxie, or tough claws. these abilities are distributed randomly throughout the lions, as is gender with the same ratio as pyroar (7:1 female:male)

the pokemon can have any moves they can legally know in-game, including obscure transfer shit, so you have some freedom to put a specific move on a specific pokemon if your argument relies on it. same with abilities. all held items for both lions and pokemon are also at your discretion, and duplicates are permitted

both sides are being controlled by trainers, so they will not be moving randomly.

the way the battle will work is all lions lined up on one side and all pokemon on the other. the fastest on the field (regieleki) will move first, then the fastest lion will move, then the next fastest pokemon, and so one. since all lions share the same speed, their order will be random. this is also true for any pokemon that share a speed stat. when everyone on a team has moved, it will go back to the start, and the fastest remaining member will move again.
this is the best way of having the battle be ordered while still having everyone fighting concurrently and not having one massive block where one billion lions move mid-battle. essentially, its most in the spirit of the original question while still maintaining some semblance of turn order

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
since triple battles are the closest analogue to this scenario, spread moves work like they do in triple battles, where very few moves hit everything on the field, and instead are concerned with adjacent pokemon. see this link for an explainer on which spread moves are which: https://pokemondb.net/move/group/multi-target

gen 9 battle mechanics will be used

if you dont like these rules, thats fine, this is simply not the thread for you. in this thread we will discuss this scenario with these rules

2/2

People forget that Generation 1 had hundreds upon hundreds of designs for monsters that pretty much all were based on pop culture before anything else. The final 151 that we got to a Western audience seem like they were based on generic RPG monsters and things like that, which some of them were, but they have far more influences from Japanese culture than we are aware of. I think Jynx being partly inspired by the yokai Yamanba would make sense. She was big in Japanese dance plays which explains the dance stuff in Jynx's Pokedex entries. She was a witch often connected with snow on the mountains which explains the Psychic/Ice typing. And she popularly looked like an ugly longhaired negress in Japanese media at the time (pic related from 1991) which explains Jynx's appearance. She even inspired some of that negroesque ganguro fashion later on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53174786
The gyaru fashion first started in the 70s having its peak between 1989-1999, Jynx's Japanese name (ルージュラ) is the same as a cosmetic brand popularly used by these girls, and both Jynx and a subcategory of this fashion are based on a yokai Yama-Uba or Yamamba, an old woman from the mountains in a red dress (due to blood in some stories) and golden or platinum hair.

For greater coincidence, Smochun has a haircut and a stylized body to that of the infant Kintaro, a legendary hero who was raised by a yama-uba.

I'm not saying that Jynx is inspired by this, just that both having a common source (Yama-Uba) it's normal for them to look alike.

I needed to try something and I've been wanting to try out a rocket-locke for a while, so I may start out a run next weekend if I finish Dead Space 2 by then.

The basics is that I can steal any pokemon from the trainer I battle first in an area (really interesting because if you can avoid trainers you have some control over the potential pools depending on trainer types). Also, to compensate for missing catches due to some areas having no trainers, I will allow myself to try capturing each gym's leader last pokemon.

But I need help deciding how to implement a dupes clause. I'm thinking that it only comes into play when the trainer I choose happens to only be carrying one single mon I already have. Because otherwise, if I'm against a trainer with 3 mons for example, and I skip the first 2 to fish for something better only to get a dupe, it just doesn't feel fair that I get to retry with another trainer: I chose to risk it and I should face the consequences.

Thoughts?

>>53148440
Empoleon
Misdreavus
Rotom (in Platinum)
Gengar
Roserade
Infernape (if you're desperate)
Golduck
Espeon

Not every single one of those is stellar, and for some you would rather use their coverage instead of choice (like Misdreavus or Gengar), but they're useable

You can always use a "regular" moveset for some of them like Calm Mind Espeon and Nasty Plot Misdreavus and just put Specs on them for fights where can tear teams apart without the setup

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53148721
NTA but I always see people talk about how good Misdreavus is, are they really good?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53149318
I would say so. They lack the setup moves in Sinnoh that make some competitive sets great (Nasty Plot is HGSS tutor only, Calm Mind is Battle Frontier only), but they have good Speed and Sp. Atk, and work as a great TM dump (Shadow Ball, Thunderbolt, Psychic, Dark Pulse), which is the sort of coverage you would want for a Specs user in DPP

Downsides are the low encounter rate (just Eterna Forest and Lost Tower), Pearl exclusive and that Dusk Stone takes a bit to show up, but it's a solid choice considering the other encounters on those areas aren't as great except for Gastly

Also, Dusk Stone in HGSS is post-game only, which makes them a lot less useful in those games

For those of you who remember (probably no one), on my last attempt Skyla wrecked in my shit. So i was pretty fucking scared going into it. Especially with 2 Fire Types. Here's what happened....

>Skyla.
I lead off with my newest lad, Quirrel the Escavalier. Acrobatics from Swoobat doesn't do much damage. About 1/3rd. X-Scissor does 95%. Swoobat heals and Quirrel goes for another X. After taking another Acrobatics, Quirrel finishes Swoobat off.

Out comes Swanna. Not my ideal situation since the strat I cooked up required Skarm to come out. No matter, I had a back-up! I send out Austin on an Air Slash. I let Austin use Light Screen while Swanna goes for another Air Slash, activating my Sitrus. Austin T-waves and gets hit with a crit Bubblebeam, leaving him on 4. hp.(*)

I send out Twoona on another Bubblebeam. Twoona plucks away Swanna's Sitrus. I send in Embuppy on the last turn of Light Screen and he takes an Air Slash extremely well. I pray to RNGsus and Emb manages to kill Swanna with Thunder Fang.

Skarm comes out last and I send in Flambill to kill it. Lava Plume leaves Skarm on a sliver, but due to Flame Body burning Skarm, it dies in 2 turns anyway.

* Another stroke of luck on my end. Going up to Skyla I had Austin hold lefties, decided to switch for a Sitrus instead since my original plan was letting Twoona set up Tail Wind on Skarm, using pluck/faint attack to ruin sturdy and finish with Tail Winded Embuppy, so Twoona having lefties would've worked better.

You guys might think overstragetizing is robbing the fun, but coming up with strats is my favorite bit of a locke.

Never played Platinum. How does it stack up to SP?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53170527
Not that anon but both games have their benefits. Platinum has more Sinnoh pokemon available (early Rotom, evolution items like Razor Fang and Reaper Cloth in the main game) as well as better teams in terms of pokemon.
BDSP has modern Pokemon features like Fairy type, better learnsets, and crit captures as well as quality of life features like HMs being tied to the Poketch and good TMs being easily available. However it misses out on Platinum's additions like a handful pokemon and items not being available till post game and updated teams. But in exchange, the Elite Four is substantially more challenging and the post game buffs up rematch teams and introduces new fights against Dawn/Lucas.

posts.com:
Weirdest Drayden fight ever.

>Drayden
I lead with Tryvern the Flygon. The strategy was ride or die AKA batshit retarded. Banking on Drayden to always press the SE button or DD up with Tryvern spamming Dragon Tail.

It immediately went sideways with Druddigon using Slash instead. And Tryvern managing to Dragon Tail out Druddigon for HAXORUS. Now here is the thing. Dragon Tail has -6 priority. I THOUGHT that if both mons have -6 priority, the speediest one should go first, right? I dumped all my Carbos on Tryvern. Flygon is faster than Haxorus.

Yet Haxorus still outsped with his Dragon Tail killing Tryvern immediately.

I send in Austin as a sacrifice. T-Wave against Dragon Dance. Reflect against Full paralysis. Then the unthinkable happens.

Austin, the smug fucker who thinks he is hot shit, manages to land all 3 Blizzards in a row against a Haxorus that uses nothing but Dragon Dance, thereby soloing Haxorus. That's right. My -defense Audino solo'd Haxorus.

Druddigon came in and Austin immediately misses Blizzard and gets Dragon Tailed out. For the mon I wanted to go into anyway, Quirrel. Quirrel dispatches the already weakened Drud with an Iron Head. Flygon comes in, but because Quirrel can't be crit, Quirrel manages to two shot the fucker with 2 X-Scissors while living on 47hp.

Funny thing was that if Tryv managed to survive, he'd replace Austin. Now I feel obligated to keep the pink fucker on.

>>53175551
alright, here's my attempt
I released my starter because I haven't done a Nuzlocke without a starter in a while and wanted to change it up (it was Oshawott).

My first two encounters were a pair of level 4 male Patrats, so I decided that they were brothers and began brainstorming. Seeing as they both had similar natures (Naughty/Likes to Run and Lonely/Thoroughly Cunning) I thought that they'd be a pair of NYC-style conmen constantly on the run. Their next destination was probably Driftveil city, since that's where all the rich miners lived, and the two had been stuck in Nuvema due to a freak flood that took them there from Route 17.

Goggles was the initial MVP, guiding his younger brother through roads only he'd been down, working mostly alone even up to the Dreamyard. While there the pair reluctantly picked up Mittens just to have a chance against Cilan's team, who'd spotted them doing shady shit with Dusk Ball Guy, and was about to call the police. Goggles convinced the gym leader team that they should just fight it out instead, and after Cilan's Pansage agreed the three went to train.
During this training, Goggles got into a grudge match with an old Patrat from his pack, and went down from a crit after taunting it one time too many, prompting Snorkel to rush to the PC.
Unfortunately, he couldn't save Goggles, and upon exiting the center he was greeted with Cheren's Snivy, who'd *also* seen the pair doing dumb shit and challenged them to a battle because the snake found their activities personally offensive due to how "dishonorable" they were. Snorkel accepted without thinking, and had nearly won the thing when Snivy struck him down with a Vine Whip. Mittens finished the fight, but-

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53176845
(In-story) Snorkel remained in critical condition, unable to fight. Mittens had to practically drag him to train at the Dreamyard, where the pair met Pillow. Pillow was mainly attracted to the pair due to Snorkel's intense dreams, and she began to form a relationship with him to get easier access to said dreams. However, she and Snorkel began actually growing close, and Snorkel even took it upon himself to tell her some things about himself that he felt she might like. The pair grew closer and closer, practically becoming friends by the time they reached the Daycare, before Snorkel passed on while Pillow and Mittens toured the place.

(In-game) He actually just died to Cheren, but I misremembered while writing this whole thing and thought he'd died after him. Therefore, he and Pillow were close. Even though they never really fought on the same team lol.

After Snorkel's passing, Mittens and Pillow felt respectively aimless. Pillow grew bitter and wanted to leave, but Mittens had been genuinely affected by Snorkel's conman rhetoric and wanted to continue forth to Driftveil both to see what it was like (since he'd never been) and to make Snorkel proud. He made Pillow stay with him to do so, and she never let him hear the end of it.

The pair continued on, recruiting Hairdo and Hannah simply through Mittens telling them his idea of Snorkel's story, eventually reaching Nacrene. While there they paid witness to a rally regarding Pokemon rights, lead by a pair of Beeheyem and their Braviary leader, stating that humans were slaveholders and outright enemies of Poke-kind. The trio were only noticed due to the massive crowd surrounding them- which happened to include a rather enthusiastic Timburr, unaware of exactly what they were preaching (he was just there for the company).

Said Timburr seemed equally-as eager to join our trio once he spotted them- for reasons currently unknown. *So* eager that he wouldn't let them leave without him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53176913
Soon after they just resolved to bring him, much to the dismay of Pillow, and said Timburr was ecstatic.

Unfortunately, he was also stubborn about fighting the strongest Pokemon in every area he visited, *single-handedly.* Mittens managed to get him to compromise and allow help if he was struggling, but the Pansear still couldn't talk Tea Burr out of it.

Tea Burr also headed straight to Pinwheel to begin training to fight Lenora, whom he'd been trying to beat for ages by that point. Unwilling to let him go alone, Hannah followed suit, leading to the rest of the team *also* training.

During that training, Mittens was hit a little too hard by a Munna whom Pillow had picked a fight with, leading to his death.
Such a fall obviously caused rifts in the team, but none were hit harder than Pillow- who not only thought this was entirely her fault, but had now grown to see Mittens as an inevitability and a part of her life who'd always just *be* there.
She reluctantly took up the mantle of team leader and instructed everyone to keep training.

So that's where we are now- everyone is training, still kind of a mess, and trying to both beat Lenora and get to Driftveil.

Talking ooc- I realize this is kind of a mess and a massive dump of boring info. I wrote a lot of it very late at night yesterday and haven't had time to organize it, so most of this is not only ad-libbed but "2am-on-two-hours-of-sleep" adlibbed haha. I'm admittedly not sure if i'll beat Lenora at all since the level gap between her team's strongest and mine is currently massive (14 to 20, jesus) but I'm willing to grind and might even try for a Gurdurr before attempting anything. Anyways, struggling has been fun, as has writing this melodramatic stuff lol. Hopefully someone else has fun reading this too.

posts.com:
back to the story...
After the Gym battle, Tea Burr and Hairdo were both fired up. Tea Burr was insistent on hitting the next gym right away- Hairdo was simply happy to support him, especially if it meant that Hairdo got stronger in the process. Hannah was just happy to be there, and Pillow... reluctantly obliged. What else did she have to do, anyways?

Just as the group were exiting the museum, however, Pillow spotted (who seemed to be) Snorkel... stealing the skull of a Dragonite skeleton! She gave chase, caught too off-guard by the imagery to question it, with her team following soon after.

The Patrat brought them to Pinwheel Forest before vanishing into the woods, unable to be seen as the quartet continued further. The woods began getting darker and darker, more and more labyrinthian... and bam!
Eventually, the group was jumped by an aggressive Venipede, gunning straight for Pillow!
Hairdo caught the thing just in time, saving the Munna with a quick Air Cutter, earning her thanks in the process.
And even more thanks were to be given, as Pillow found a timid Sewaddle shaking where the Venipede once stood.

The next few minutes consisted of her blubbering gratitudes to the group, personally shaking each mon's hand (and Hannah's foot), before taking one look at Hairdo and realizing she was probably safer with Pillow.

Too tired to object to the Sewaddle tagging along, Pillow and her gang continued moving through the forest, with Sylvia insisting on taking out every opponent in their way as thanks... even after she evolved.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Just finished preparing my team for Juan, only to realize I need a surf mon to even get to the gym. Goddammit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Finally beat Juan, deathless even, after a ton of prep, I was pretty nervous about it JUST because of that damn Double Team Rest spamming Kingdra. But I'm very thankful for that issue about me needing a surfmon, I was initially going to bring Tropius for Sunny Day + Whirlwind shenanigans but thank god I didn't. Walrien ended up being a perfect wall against Kingdra.

I was REALLY wanting to lead with Castform, but I couldn't risk him getting infatuated while setting up the sun, so I just went with Sceptile to take out Luvdisc and Sealeo. But then came the Kingdra.

I went into Walrien and attempted to Encore it into Double Team, but ofc it missed. Then I tried hitting it with Blizzards, but ofc it missed multiple times, eventually hitting it hard. I swapped to Absol during his healing turn to initiate my wacky strat, Perish Song force switch. It worked and was able to take out the Whiscash he brought in, but out came the Kingdra again.

This time however I was able to successfully encore him into Double Team, so I switched into my Guts boosted Swellow to hit some Aerial Aces, but encore wore soon so I had to do multiple switches to get Absol back in safely (and thankfully with no confusion) to Perish Song once again. During the perish counter wait, I set up Hail for chip damage.

Finally, I switch into Manectric to take out the Crawdaunt, and when his Kingdra came out once more, I decided to risk it and hit a Thunderbolt, which thankfully killed.

Sorry for the long post, but this battle was pretty nutty. It's funny this is the second time I used Perish Song against Kingdra, earlier I did so against Clair in Crystal, but her AI is predictable so I was able to take it out with it.

~I have returned~
and with me comes a story update

As the gang passed through Castelia, they saw it fit to take a rest...
What followed was a week or two of getting their bearings. Sylvia was formally introduced to everyone else, happily embraced by Tea Burr and Hannah while being somewhat accepted by the other two. Some items were scrounged up from bins while they tried to find something to eat: notably in this case, a Quick Claw for Pillow (which she would then go on to make great use of) and a Miracle Seed for Sylvia.

The collective went their separate ways while they rested, still unsure of how to go about things and all with conflicting desires.
Tea Burr wanted to rush straight to the gym, but was thankfully deterred by Hairdo, instead prompting him to tour the Battle Company nearby.
Hairdo himself was too busy getting an overview of the city. It'd been a while since he could spread his wings, and there was no way he'd pass up an opportunity to do so in a city with heights like these.
Pillow instead took to alleyways and the Casteliacone stand, halfheartedly attempting to commit Grand Theft Ice Cream in some vain attempt to live up to what Snorkel had set out to do, before folding and just going to join Hannah...

...who'd befriended a local trio of dancers, and was outright earning money doing breakdancing.
Huzzah?

[cntd]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53184172
...eventually, the week of rest came to an end.

Sylvia found herself pulling away from all the art galleries she'd hit up, eventually wandering back to Pillow.
Hairdo sought out Tea Burr, soon enough, only to find the Timburr still staring at gym, just as eager to see the Tranquil as he had been when they first parted.
And Hannah...
...well, it was a lot harder to pull her away from breakdancing, but she eventually decided to give it a break once Pillow proposed her plan.
After such a proposal, the Munna and her companions also sought out the other two mon formerly with them, and explained how things were going to go.

Pillow was unsure if Snorkel was really dead or alive. She explained that she was going to travel the region to seek him out, and that Sylvia wanted to help too. Whoever else wanted to was welcome to join.
Sylvia, on the other hand, was a lot more emotional about it- *she* had grown used to the group being together, and essentially gave a stuttering speech about how well they all worked as a team, and how much she'd rather they stick together.

Tea Burr needed no convincing, he wasn't leaving. Hannah was relatively on-board with the idea, too.
Hairdo...
...
...decided not to go.
He said his goodbyes to Tea, gave a half-hearted departure to the other three, and took off.

And yet, as the quartet headed out to the Route 4 desert, they'd occasionally find a grey quill or two dropping down from above, along with a shadow that never seemed to leave them...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
update time
ignore that I completely forgot to include the fact that they all beat the gym *last time* and I just didn't mention it, they did that and it went very smoothly
anyways-

The gang trekked on through the desert, the high of their previous gym battle beginning to wear off as the sandstorm they now faced wore them down one by one. Each member was becoming more and more tired, until-
Pillow shouted. She saw Snorkel again, but this time she was *sure* it was him. The Munna didn't hesitate to detour- though, she took some time to make sure Sylvia and Hannah were following at the very least. Tea came soon after, of course, unwilling to leave his friends behind.

As they gave chase, the quartet started to lose track... until they were jumped by a swarm of- humans?
Brainwashed humans, dressed up in some sort of medieval templar gear, that didn't hesitate to go straight for the party and try to keep them away from wherever Snorkel was going!

Tea and Hannah wasted no time in fighting them off, with the former taking down grunts swiftly while the latter stalled until the grunts could go on no more. Hannah's grunts usually ended up lucid- Tea's ended up abused. Either way, the two nearly took care of them, before another wave attacked!

And with that wave came someone else- Hairdo, who'd been watching from above (totally a twist nobody saw coming whatsoever)! He dropped in to offer support, assisting the pair in taking down the rest of the grunts...
...after which, both Hannah and Tea evolved!! (in-game the former evolved after fighting Bianca and the latter after fighting a random trainer, but shhh story)

While the two celebrated their achievement, however, Sylvia was there to remind them of what they were really after- the Patrat that'd now started towards Relic Castle.
Without hesitation, everyone refocused and headed towards Desert Resort...

[cntd]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53184860
The trip to Desert Resort went smoothly, if briefly. It was a little too short for everyone to start asking important questions or making game plans- by the time Tea raised his arm to give a heartfelt speech about always knowing Hairdo would come back to them in time, the group had already been ambushed by more grunts upon reaching their destination.

Most of the members were caught completely off-guard, with only Hairdo remaining fit enough to fight them off. But even he eventually became overwhelmed...
...before he gained an ally in a Sigilpyh flying nearby! She flew in to intercept the battle, blowing away the grunts with ease with her Whirlwind. She promptly introduced herself to the Tranquil as Daga, before Hairdo explained what he was after.
He took an aside to glance over to his teammates. Most of them were unconscious, and Pillow was too wounded to float...
...the Sigilyph saw this situation and tried to do what she could. Daga carefully brought most of the team over to a kind human doctor, one at a time. When Hairdo began to question her trusting of a human stranger, Daga instead told him not to worry and guided him to the Relic Castle.

Once they got there, the pair properly laid eyes upon Snorkel for the first time, only to find him stealing a pair of fossils!
Daga tried to intercept, only to get blown back with a Bite and challenged to a battle. She accepted, and Hairdo was restrained while it commenced. Desperately trying to free himself, the Tranquil soon managed it with the help of a small Sandile trying to save the fossils.

Daga was ultimately beaten, but Hairdo knocked Snorkel to the side just in time, managing to save... one fossil, before getting bitten himself just as the Patrat fled.

Once the dust had settled, Hairdo was left with a feathery-looking fossil and a shy Sandile refusing to come out from under his wing. Daga lay on the ground in critical condition, all the grunts had been defeated, and Hairdo... needed a moment.

>I guess fantasy stuff? You working on anything currently?
I have one story I'm working on lately about a witch fleeing the trials of late 1600s America, and jumping on the westward expansion bandwagon to get away (I'm fudging the dates a bit from historical realism). It's half a story about someone trying to live in peace and do the right thing when the demands of survival are so high, and half about how you can never really hide who you are no matter how far you run so it's better to just find a home that loves you back to grow in. It may sound a bit cringy when you lay it out like this, but I'm enjoying it.

I also basically always hafve DnD/PF writing going. Characters, campaigns, worldbuilding, this stuff never really ends and it stays a creative outlet for me when I'm running out of other ideas.

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

>Wiki
https://pokeclicker.miraheze.org/wiki/Home_Page

You're supposed to make most of your diamonds by chaining underground daily deals.
Which is funny, because this is technically exploiting a poor RNG algorithm that makes the random deals predictable, but the devs just let players rely on it instead of balancing the minigame. In a recent patch, they even went out of their way to make sure an update didn't fuck up the 100 days long chain their Discord bot came up with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53135996
>technically exploiting a poor RNG algorithm

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53136204
I don't know the details, just that the deals that appear each day are supposed to be random; there is not a fixed schedule. But at some point someone figured out how to predict the randomness, probably because the code responsible is not too complex. With that information, someone else made a bot that forecasts future deals and can be found at the official Discord. That's where the chains that appear in this thread from time to time come from.
So it's technically an exploit, but "officially" recognized, in part because this way the devs don't feel the need to make the Underground not shit, but also because they don't want to deal with their "hardcore" players throwing a hissy fit if they mess with their chains.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53136681

I think the answer for your question is because Roaring Moon has potential that hasn't been tapped into yet. >>53185202
Well once you cross the threshold to a certain rank you can't go down again even if you continuously lose (so you'll never drop from Great Ball back down to Poke Ball) though you can drop from say Great Ball level 2 to level one. Also, once you reach Master Ball, you'll have to win at least one for your Pokémon to get the ribbons.

The rest is honestly just knowing the meta, like what the most common Pokémon and strategies are and how to counter them. For example, if doing doubles, if someone has a bunch of slow, powerful mons plus Indeedee plus Farigariff then it's obviously a Trick Room team and you should have a counter for it. Season 2 is the first one that allows Paradox so you should have a work around for Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane who I'd argue are the two most common.

It's tough to give you more advice than that without knowing the team you're using though.

their are specific nuances to a characters design that i like preserved
you can go a little free form with like clothes and what not, but once you start deviating from the overall character its a no go for me
to avoid "lol you are just a pedo" talk, lets use cynthia as an example first
sure she is a human character, but if I want to keep thinking thats her i would want her as close to official proportions and art style as possible
its not just about "keeping her chest small"
i like the official pokemon designs and want it to stay that way
also, this does not mean anything can deviate
you can play around with some things to match a preferred feel especially in terms of perspective which might make the characters design feel strange in an angle its not used to being in
but once you start going into "omega triple D tits" on a character that was not designed for it, then thats not the same character in my eyes
now its just some plastic porn star in cosplay

>>53176767
Ultimately I would rather have an artist draw the character as they perceive them in their own style rather than sticking to concept art.
I also really like the official Pokemon designs, but there's no need to stick to them religiously.
That concept art was made to be used internally to make sure the characters looked consistent from frame to frame. It was never anyone's intent that the fans should have to follow it as well.
The point of making fan art is to have fun. Adding a whole bunch of rules on top of that might make the art more consistent, but I feel like something valuable is lost in the process.

Now I'm not an advocate for "ON MODEL ONLY" at all times.
Expression is a key foundation in art it should be preserved. Its just a personal taste to be as close as possible.
Like here, there some liberties being taken with how the legs work and some of the proportions of the hips and whatnot, but it still feels like a Spinda.
The legs move in a very strange way with the actual model. Lots of stretch and almost impossible to see ankles. So it can be awkward to work with that design in many aspects, but some liberty taken that makes sense for the design while keeping the heart is always a bonus and can really show off the artist skill and the appreciation for the source material.

posts.com:
So, after what I'm pretty has at least been a 15 years since I have last seen Heroes, I finally rewatched it and watched it in subs too. I still feel the same way I did the last time I have seen it: loved it.
There are a few things I want to mention: the 3D surprisingly doesn't stick out like a sore thumb, that was something I was worried about on rewatch as it might've took me right out of the experience. I never realized how borderline useless Misty and Brock were in this film; if it were not for one scene late into the film, one could've removed them and the plot wouldn't change, this film, for all intents and purposes, was a film between Ash and Latias. I never realized Latias has a leitmotif, it being derived from the song "Search for the Girl," and it being first used when Ash meets Latias in her human disguise and again at the end when she runs up onto the dock to see Ash one last time. This film made me realized that Ash being Thunderbolt'd to save Latias wasn't his first time, he did that here when he jumped into Aerodactyl to save Latias and asked Pikachu to use Thunderbolt on the former while Ash was still on it. Final moment I want to mention, the credit song, "You're Not Alone," is lovely but I can't help but do a stretch, it feels like a song from Latias to Ash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53169447
Haha, thank you for this! I am Norwegian and can give you my review on this after watching for a bit.

They are voiced by the same few VAs every single Norwegian dub of any every single animated show had back in the days. And I mean every single show. I suppose the market for Norwegian dub voice actors weren't the biggest, so these few voices more or less did every dub on TV.
I find it nostalgic but at the same time hearing Ash speak my language feels pretty weird. It sounds so over-the-top I can't help but laugh at times(and Ash is clearly voiced by someone 20+ years of age). When Latias reveals herself and Lorenzo comments "Hun må virkelig like denne unge mannen, gitt!"("She must really like this young man, geez"), it is delivered in a pretty hilarious way void of any emotion, but at the same time sounding like an old Norwegian sailor stereotype.
I really don't know how I would rate this, but I love that the dub exists regardless. This came out in DVD form with the box art being localized for Norwegian as well. Overall I don't think the quality is bad, I just don't have any reference to compare it to. Wholesome/10!

>>53169809
Thanks a million for this anon!
I am a swede, so the Norwegian dubs were on all the DVDs, and have always been an option on Netflix over here.
I really enjoy the flow and intonation of Norwegian, and as >>53169809 mentions Ash sounds like a proper man, which is a lot of fun to me. I always make sure to watch any movies I can a second time in Norwegian.
I have great respect for both the Swedish and Norwegian VAs since most of them have stayed with their respective characters through the entire series since day one. Most probably beacause they are, as anon also mentioned, the few bargain-bin voices who are in every animated show ever (also respect).
The Scandinavian dubs can be hard to find in the digital age of English, so this in particular is a great treat.
The best version of the M5 race song is the Danish one, though. So if one were a crazy autist, one would dance between the DVD dub tracks when that song comes on.

>>53170998
From what I have seen/heard around it's basically because the movie is a good movie, not just a good Pokemon movie but a good movie in general.
It's visuals are really good and nice to see (and have aged really well), the plot is nice and pretty interesting too and the characters and their interactions/relationships are compelling and fun to witness, especially when it comes to Ash and Latias who share what is probably one of the closest things to a romance plot the anime has had without being too in your face about it (it's sometimes described as a surprising "boy meets girl" story), and has a really emotional climax that makes you feel for the characters involved alongside a really sweet ending.
It's overall a really nice and compelling story to watch that has a lot of heart put into it and is enjoyable even after all these years.

>Eternal youth is part of his motivation
Eternal youth is metaphorical.
His goal is to create a sustainable society, which in his twisted mind meant culling humans and wiping out Pokemon (yes, he wanted to kill all Pokemon, even his own, people forget that detail). He believed that unchecked population growth would inevitably lead to war and over-consumption of the world's finite resources.
Team Flare's obsession with beauty was mostly them misinterpreting Lysandre's words, believing that they were chosen by him for being beautiful people, when in reality they're just some spoiled rich fucks and Lysandre was an unironic "just stop being poor" elite who blamed the have nots for being lazy.

The Tunguska event (occasionally also called the Tunguska incident) was an approximately 12-megaton[2] explosion that occurred near the Podkamennaya Tunguska River in Yeniseysk Governorate (now Krasnoyarsk Krai), Russia, on the morning of June 30, 1908.[1][3] The explosion over the sparsely populated Eastern Siberian Taiga flattened an estimated 80 million trees over an area of 2,150 km2 (830 sq mi) of forest, and eyewitness reports suggest that at least three people may have died in the event.[4][5][6][7][2] The explosion is generally attributed to a meteor air burst: the atmospheric explosion of a stony asteroid about 50–60 metres (160–200 feet) in size.[2][8]:p. 178 The asteroid approached from the east-southeast, and likely with a relatively high speed of about 27 km/s (60,000 mph) (~Ma 80).[2] It is classified as an impact event, even though no impact crater has been found; the object is thought to have disintegrated at an altitude of 5 to 10 kilometres (3 to 6 miles) rather than having hit the surface of the Earth.[9]

*From wiki

Essentially, you are trying to get as much PMUP on her before she dishes out her Fly using Metronome. She has Super Powered 5, so her Fly WILL hit hard. (Although she needs accuracy buffs). If you run her off-type, all you need is Metronome.

That's just it though? Its RNG based, but Metronome is 2/3 special attacks except fissure. So you're gonna have a good time stacking PMUP. Her Drill Peck also does a lot of damage as well especially on ontype.

I probably wouldn't recommend it unless you like her, or you need a Physical Striker for Flying-types.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53168114
Look at the leaderboards for inspiration, it’s gauntlet so people inevitably have to start using F2P/non-limited pairs.

For Latias you want a debuffer that hits at least two stats per turn. Lucian and Janine/Ariados are good non-limited options, Kiawe could also work if you have another single debuffer to supplement him. May/Blaziken, not-Champion Iris and Serena/Greninja are easy mode clears.

For Uxie you want to use something that can burn/poison/paralyze reliably, plus a trapper.

Regirock you can just bonk it really hard with physical strikers, and maybe use units you can grid to disable defense debuffs on.

The battle system itself is fun, sort of the second try for triple battles, but you will see most of what the game has to offer (Battle Villa, Elite 4, Legendary Battle Gauntlets) in two to three months time, after which you are powering up your characters and occasionally spinning the slots for new ones to continue playing those same modes more effectively, though the specific battles do rotate. The special costumes and trainer lodge guests tend toward ladies, what with the female player characters having thrice the costumes the boys do, while Steven, N, Morty, and the Subway bros take a lot of the male real estate, but I don't have a ratio off the top of my head. posts.com:
Some fun facts, because I'm bored:
Elesa is the only character with four different outfits to have never been paired with a Legendary/Mythical Pokémon.

Leaf is the only female main character to have less outfits than her male counterpart. This was also true with Hilda after Hilbert's Halloween costume, until she got her special costume with Diancie.

Sygna Suit Lysandre is the first male sync pair in nearly two months, since Champion Calem.

Lillie is the only character with four different outfits where none of her outfits are a Sygna Suit. Conversely, Cynthia is the only character with four different outfits where all of her alt outfits are Sygna Suits.

To this day, there are only two characters who have received alt outfits who are neither 5* nor story characters, those being Siebold and Whitney, with a nearly 3 year gap between their releases.

Ash is (to my knowledge) the only character to have voice lines mentioning his partner Pokémon's name.

The trainer moves of Bugsy (Scyther) and Sygna Suit Blue have the exact same effect.

INT. QUAHOG LIVING ROOM - DAY

PETER is playing a Pokemon video game on the couch.

PETER
(excitedly)
Yes! I caught a Pikachu!

Suddenly, a bright light envelops Peter and he disappears.

EXT. POKEMON WORLD - DAY

Peter finds himself in a strange new world filled with colorful creatures.

PETER
(looking around in amazement)
What the hell? I must be in the Pokemon world!

Peter sees a Pikachu and starts chasing it.

PETER
(excitedly)
Pikachu, I choose you!

PETER (CONT’D)
(realizing something)
Wait a minute, I can actually catch these things?!

Peter goes on a wild adventure, catching all kinds of Pokemon and battling other trainers. Along the way, he meets various Pokemon characters, including ASH, BULBASAUR, and CHARIZARD.

PETER
(excitedly)
I’m gonna be the very best, like no one ever was!

ASH
(skeptically)
I’ve never seen a human like you before. What’s your strategy?

PETER
(confidently)
Eat, drink, and be merry!

Peter’s unique approach to Pokemon training quickly gains him a reputation as the wild card of the Pokemon world.

EXT. POKEMON LEAGUE STADIUM - DAY

Peter stands face-to-face with the Pokemon League Champion.

PETER
(determined)
I’ve come this far, and I’m not gonna back down now.

The battle is intense, but Peter ultimately triumphs and becomes the Pokemon League Champion.

PETER (CONT’D)
(excitedly)
I did it! I’m the very best!

Suddenly, Peter finds himself back in the Quahog living room, holding a Pikachu toy.

PETER (CONT’D)
(disappointed)
Wait a minute, it was all just a dream?

The family dog, BRIAN, walks in and snatches the Pikachu toy from Peter.

BRIAN
(sarcastically)
I’m the Pokemon master now.

Peter groans in frustration as the scene fades to black.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53159234
Not how it works, each player spawns his own Pokemon.
It's why the guide multiple times says to be far apart, because if scarlet player is near violet player, violet player will only render 5 spawns max so he gets 3 violet paradox, then the scarlet near him spawns 2 scarlet paradoxes and scarlet sees 3 violet.
Instead of getting 10 max spawns, 10 shiny rolls, you're only getting 5.
The scarlet paradoxes belong and were spawned by the scarlet player, so they have the effects of the scarlet player while the violet player paradoxes has violet player effects.


So if violet eats teensy 3 and scarlet eats humong 3, violet gets 3 teensy spawns and the other 2 scarlet paradox will be humongo

>>53182110
>QotT: What was your most recent legendary hunt?
I seldom ever hunt for legendaries, mostly because the odds are never as good as stuff like Sandwich hunting or SOS Encounters, plus I don't particularly care for most shiny legendaries in the first place. That was, until I found out I could get shiny Reshiram. Its shiny form isn't all too different from its normal form, but I like Reshiram and I liked the shiny color anyways so I went about hunting for it
>Did you get it?
I started my hunt in ORAS, but after ~500 SRs I sort of just stopped and did other stuff. Not because I outright gave up, I was intending to continue later but just never bothered going back. Eventually, USUM came out and I found out that not only could I get shiny Reshiram there as well, but I could also try for a Beast Ball, which I really like and caught pretty much everything in save for normal Legendaries

Sure enough, after a few more soft resets I eventually found it, put on a Lv. 3 Roto Catch Power, weakened it, put it to sleep and just went to town throwing Beast Ball after Beast Ball. Unfortunately I never considered how unlikely this would be to catch. If I did I would've gotten a Pokemon to give it a Leppa Berry with Harvest so it doesn't struggle. Thankfully I managed to catch it before that point, but just barely. It had ~8 or so uses of Extrasensory left, so I was very lucky there

I still have it in my copy of Ultra Sun for now, but I'm thinking of trading it up to HOME soon so I can use it in Scarlet & Violet's DLC, because you know they're likely going to bring it back when that happens. I also want to fix its nature with a mint, since it's Serious natured. Funily enough, that's the same nature as my Reshiram in Black when I first played it

roster is good, matchmaking is ass

made it to 1600 early last season, was going toe to toe against pro players and streamers, winning against sweaty 3stacks, and overall was enjoying the game playing with people that somewhat knew how to play

Then at the mid/end of the season all the shitters with inflated ranks started climbing with 42% winrates and they were making every match unplayable, matches went from being enjoyable to being a 10 minutes long shitfests that no one enjoyed

i was waiting for the rank reset to send these shitters back to vet, but when the season started i got hardstuck in ultra. This season after 100 matches i was still in ultra 2, while last season after 40 matches i was in master. This isn't my first moba so i know there was some fuckery going on, i kept getting some of the worst teammates i had ever seen, i was getting paired with people that had 90 games total and barely knew how to play

I don't have it in me to keep grinding with these shit teams, the game is simply unenjoyable, i used to be able to rely on my teammates when i was in high master, got used to that playstyle, played for the team, but that kind of playstyle is what got me hardstuck in ultra now and i can't bring myself to go back to playing 1v9 hypercarries anymore

So yeah i'm skipping this season and waiting for the next rank reset. I'm playing other stuff in the meanwhile, they can add all the pokemons and all the maid outfits they want, the game will still be shit until they fix the matchmaking
